moduleGroup.name: DTI eddy motion data with two repeats
moduleGroup.description: Correct for eddy current induced distortions & motion artifacts using data with two repeats

module.name: Align Linear
module.description:
This is a general linear intramodality registration tool (within or across subjects, 2D or 3D). The user can specify any of a variety of models, including rigid-body, affine, or perspective.
The program will generate a .air file that can be used to reslice the specified reslice data set to match the specified standard data set.
64-bit compilation

citations.citation: Woods, R.P., Grafton, S.T., Holmes, C.J., Cherry, S.R., and Mazziotta, J.C. (1998a). Automated image registration: I. General methods and intrasubject, intramodality validation. J Comput Assist Tomogr V22, 139-152. PMID: 9448779

Woods, R.P., Grafton, S.T., Watson, J.D., Sicotte, N.L., and Mazziotta, J.C. (1998b). Automated image registration: II. Intersubject validation of linear and nonlinear models. J Comput Assist Tomogr 22, 153-165. PMID: 9448780

input.name: Standard Volume
input.description: The atlas that the input file is resliced to match.

input.name: Reslice Volume
input.description: The input being registered to the standard-file.

output.name: Linear Transformation
output.description: Resultant linear spatial transformation matrix saved as a .air file

input.name: Model Number
input.description: Defines the degrees of freedom of the transformation. 3-D models: 6. rigid body 6 parameter model 7. global rescale 7 parameter model 9. traditional 9 parameter model (std must be on AC-PC line) 12. affine 12 parameter model 15. perspective 15 parameter model 2-D models (constrained to in-plane, no interpolation): 23. 2-D rigid body 3 parameter model 24. 2-D global rescale 4 parameter model 25. 2-D affine/fixed determinant 5 parameter model 26. 2-D affine 6 parameter model 28. 2-D perspective 8 parameter model AIR 5.0

input.name: Threshold Standard
input.description: The threshold for the Standard Volume defines a minimum voxel value. Voxels in the Standard Volume with intensities below this value are excluded from analysis when computing the cost function and its derivatives. The value should always be an integer less than the maximum voxel value in the corresponding file.

input.name: Threshold Reslice
input.description: The threshold for the Reslice Volume defines a minimum voxel value. Voxels in the Reslice Volume with intensities below this value are excluded from analysis when computing the cost function and its derivatives. The value should always be an integer less than the maximum voxel value in the corresponding file.

input.name: Blur Standard
input.description: The Gaussian smoothing filter for the Standard Volume. Smoothing filters are applied along the x, y, and z axes of the Standard Volume before performing registration. The FWHM value specifies the full width at half maximum of the Gaussian smoothing filter to be applied along each dimension. The filters have units of millimeters (or whatever units you use to specify voxel sizes in your .hdr files). All three dimensions must be specified. If you give a value of zero, no smoothing will be applied along the corresponding dimension.

input.name: Blur Reslice
input.description: The Gaussian smoothing filter for the Reslice Volume. Smoothing filters are applied along the x, y, and z axes of the Reslice Volume before performing registration. The FWHM value specifies the full width at half maximum of the Gaussian smoothing filter to be applied along each dimension. The filters have units of millimeters (or whatever units you use to specify voxel sizes in your .hdr files). All three dimensions must be specified. If you give a value of zero, no smoothing will be applied along the corresponding dimension.

input.name: Segment Standard
input.description:
Number of partitions for the standard image. This defines the number of partitions used for segmenting the standard file in the forward direction WHEN USING THE STANDARD DEVIATION OF THE RATIO IMAGE AS THE COST FUNCITON. If this value is zero, no forward direction computation is performed. A value of 256 is typically used for intermodality registration when the corresponding file is an MRI study. For MRI-PET registration, the number of partitions corresponding to the PET study should be set to zero. When registering two dissimilar MR images, both data sets can be assigned 256 partitions. For intramodality registration, the default value of 1 is appropriate.
AIR 5.0 Note that AIR now uses dynamic partitioning by default. Instead of dividing the theoretical range of voxel intensities into the designated number of partitions, the actual range of voxel intensities is divided into this number of partitions. This assures that when the dynamic range of the data is restricted, the voxels do not all end up occupying far fewer partitions than requested. The "Static Partitioning" option forces the use of static partitioning as in AIR 3.0x.

input.name: Segment Reslice
input.description:
Number of partitions for the Reslice Volume. This defines the number of partitions used for segmenting the Reslice Volume in the reverse direction WHEN USING THE STANDARD DEVIATION OF THE RATIO IMAGE AS THE COST FUNCITON. If this value is zero, no reverse direction computation is performed. A value of 256 is typically used for intermodality registration when the corresponding file is an MRI study. For MRI-PET registration, the number of partitions corresponding to the PET study should be set to zero. When registering two dissimilar MR images, both data sets can be assigned 256 partitions. For intramodality registration, the default value of 1 is appropriate.
AIR 5.0 Note that AIR now uses dynamic partitioning by default. Instead of dividing the theoretical range of voxel intensities into the designated number of partitions, the actual range of voxel intensities is divided into this number of partitions. This assures that when the dynamic range of the data is restricted, the voxels do not all end up occupying far fewer partitions than requested. The "Static Partitioning" option forces the use of static partitioning as in AIR 3.0x.

input.name: Standard Mask Volume
input.description: This volume is applied to the Standard Volume as a mask. The file must match the corresponding file's dimensions, and voxels that are zero in this file will be treated as if they were zero in the corresponding file when computing the cost function. Mask files can be binary or regular files.

input.name: Reslice Mask Volume
input.description: This volume is applied to the Reslice Volume as a mask. The file must match the corresponding file's dimensions, and voxels that are zero in this file will be treated as if they were zero in the corresponding file when computing the cost function. Mask files can be binary or regular files.

input.name: Spatial Initialization
input.description: An ASCII file containing spatial transformation initialization parameters. These parameters can be used to control the starting position for automated registration, a feature that is useful if the initial misregistration is extreme (e.g., > 45 degrees of rotational misregistration) or if the default registration leads to an obviously incorrect result. Different spatial models require different numbers and types of parameters in the initialization file. Note that some cost functions may also allow an intensity parameter initialization file as well.

output.name: Spatial Termination
output.description: An ASCII file to be created containing spatial transformation termination parameters. These parameters can then be used as initialization parameters to restart the algorithm at the same location in parameter space where it left off (using the same spatial model). This allows you to switch cost functions or to vary smoothing, among other things. Different spatial models create incompatible files. Note that some cost functions may also allow an intensity parameter termination file.

input.name: Scaling Initialization
input.description: An ASCII file containing a single parameter that initializes intensity scaling.

output.name: Scaling Termination
output.description: An ASCII file containing the intensity scaling parameter identified as optimal by the algorithm. Combined with a spatial transformation initialization file, this parameter can be used to restart the algorithm at the same location in parameter space where it left off. In addition, the scaling parameter can be used as an intensity normalization factor for subsequent statistical analysis of the registered data or as input to reslice to create a final image that is intensity corrected as well as spatially corrrected.

input.name: Samplings
input.description: Determines the number of intermediate iterative cycles of the algorithm. The current sampling is divided by this ratio with each cycle to determine the new sampling.

input.name: Convergence Threshold
input.description: Controls how small the predicted change in the cost function must be in order to meet the convergence criteria. Setting this value too large will result in convergence while the images are still misregistered; setting it too small may lead to a failure to converge.

input.name: Repeated Iterations
input.description: The maximum number of iterations permitted at each sampling density. If this number is made too low, it will lead to inaccurate results and/or slow down the overall performance of the algorithm by preventing you from making use of information that could have been derived more quickly at the prematurely aborted, more superficial sampling.

input.name: Halt After Steps Without Improvement
input.description: The maximum number of iterations without any observed improvement in the cost function. If greater than or equal to repeated-iterations, this value has no effect. At lower values, it can help you escape from situations where you are bouncing back and forth between two or three locations in parameter space without making any real progress. This sort of thing usually only happens at superficial sampling densities.

input.name: Use Non-positive Definite Hessian Matrices
input.description: A currently unvalidated method for overcoming non-positive definite Hessian matrices.

input.name: Static Partitioning (AIR 3.0 compatible)
input.description: Forces the use of static partitioning, reverting to the default behavior of AIR 3.0x.

input.name: Non-interaction of Spatial Parameter Derivatives
input.description: Assumes a non-interaction of spatial parameter derivatives (reduces likelihood of non-positive definite Hessian matrices).

input.name: Verbose
input.description: Extremely detailed reporting of interim results.

input.name: Pre-alignment Interpolation
input.description: Provides pre-alignment interpolation to cubic voxels.

input.name: Cost Function
input.description:
The cost function to be used for alignemtn as selected from the following menu: 1. Standard deviation of ratio images cost function: This cost function has the advantage of being independent of image intensity, so image intensities can be poorly matched and the registration will not be adversely affected. This is the only model that allows multiple partitions as required for intermodality registration.
2. Least squares cost function: This cost function assumes that the image intensities are scaled identically. Least squares is computationally simpler and therefore faster than the standard deviation of ratio images, but may be inaccurate if the image intensities are poorly matched.
3. Least squares with global rescaling cost function This cost function is identical to the least squares cost function except that an intensity scaling term is added to the model.

module.name: Align Warp
module.description:
This is a nonlinear registration tool that can be used within or across subjects and includes implementation of 2D and 3D nonlinear spatial transformation models.
The program will generate a .warp file that can be used to reslice the specified reslice data set to match the specified standard data set.
http://bishopw.loni.ucla.edu/AIR5/align_warp.html

citations.citation: Woods, R.P., Grafton, S.T., Holmes, C.J., Cherry, S.R., and Mazziotta, J.C. (1998a). Automated image registration: I. General methods and intrasubject, intramodality validation. J Comput Assist Tomogr V22, 139-152. PMID: 9448779

Woods, R.P., Grafton, S.T., Watson, J.D., Sicotte, N.L., and Mazziotta, J.C. (1998b). Automated image registration: II. Intersubject validation of linear and nonlinear models. J Comput Assist Tomogr 22, 153-165. PMID: 9448780

input.name: Standard Volume
input.description: The name of the file that you want the other file resliced to match. The standard file will often be an atlas, but can also be images from a single subject.

input.name: Reslice Volume
input.description: The name of the file you want registered to the standard volume

output.name: .warp-out
output.description: The exact name of the .warp transformation parameter output file (cannot contain '.img' or '.hdr').

input.name: Model Menu Number
input.description: The menu number, from the model menu listed above, of the polynomial transformation to be used initially for spatial transformation. Note that this parameter was changed in AIR 5.0 such that this is always the initial model used, regardless of the presence of the optional final-model-menu-number. If no final-model-menu-number is provided, the algorithm starts and ends with the model specified here.

input.name: Final Model Menu Number
input.description: Models are incremented sequentially from the model-menu-number to this the model from the model menu that corresponds to this value. If the algorithm fails to improve the parameters at a given polynomial order,this final value will not be reached.

input.name: Blur Standard
input.description: If this option is used, smoothing filters are applied along the x, y and z axes of the standard file before performing registration. The FWHM value specifies the full width at half maximum of the Gaussian smoothing filter to be applied along each dimension. The filters have units of millimeters (or whatever units you use to specify voxel sizes in your .hdr files). All three dimensions must be specified. If you give a value of zero, no smoothing will be applied along the corresponding dimension.

input.name: Blur Reslice
input.description: If this option is used, smoothing filters are applied along the x, y and z axes of the reslice file before performing registration. The FWHM value specifies the full width at half maximum of the Gaussian smoothing filter to be applied along each dimension. The filters have units of millimeters (or whatever units you use to specify voxel sizes in your .hdr files). All three dimensions must be specified. If you give a value of zero, no smoothing will be applied along the corresponding dimension.

input.name: Convergence Threshold
input.description: Controls how small the predicted change in the cost function must be in order to meet the convergence criteria. Setting this value too large will result in convergence while the images are still misregistered; setting it too small may lead to a failure to converge.

input.name: Mask Standard
input.description: This file is applied to the standard file as a mask. The file must match the corresponding file's dimensions, and voxels that are zero in this file will be treated as if they were zero in the corresponding file when computing the cost function. Mask files can be binary or regular files.

input.name: Mask Reslice
input.description: This file is applied to the reslice file as a mask. The file must match the corresponding file's dimensions, and voxels that are zero in this file will be treated as if they were zero in the corresponding file when computing the cost function. Mask files can be binary or regular files.

input.name: Warp Initialization
input.description: The name of a .warp file to be used to initialize the spatial transformation. Starting with AIR 5.2.3, the order of this file can be either equal to or one less than that of the Model Menu Number. Earlier versions of AIR 5 will only allow orders that are one less than that of the model-menu-number. First (AIR 5.2.3 and later) or second order spatial transformations may also be initialized using a .air file rather than a .warp file provided that the .air file does not use perspective transformations. Prior to AIR 5.0, ASCII files were used for initialization purposes. This is no longer supported. Note that intensity scaling must be initialized separately using the Scaling Initialization.

input.name: Scaling Initialization
input.description: The name of an ASCII file containing a single parameter that initializes intensity scaling

output.name: Scaling Termination
output.description: The name of an ASCII file to be created containing the intensity scaling parameter identified as optimal by the algorithm. Combined with a .warp file, this parameter can be used to restart the algorithm at the same location in parameter space where it left off. In addition, the scaling parameter can be used as an intensity normalization factor for subsequent statistical analysis of the registered data or as input to reslice_warp to create a final image that is intensity corrected as well as spatially corrrected.

input.name: Halt after N iterations without improvement
input.description: Controls the maximum number of iterations without any observed improvement in the cost function. If greater than or equal to repeated-iterations, this value has no effect. At lower values, it can help you escape from situations where you are bouncing back and forth between two or three locations in parameter space without making any real progress. This sort of thing usually only happens at superficial sampling densities.

output.name: Save Intermediate .warp Files
output.description: Enables saving (with overwrite permission) of intermediate .warp files for each incremental model

input.name: Use Non-positive Definite Hessian Matrices
input.description: Uses currently unvalidated method for overcoming non-positive definite Hessian matrices

input.name: Non-interaction of Spatial Parameter Derivatives
input.description: Assumes non-interaction of spatial parameter derivatives (reduces likelihood of non-positive definite Hessian matrices)

input.name: Maximum Iterations
input.description: Controls the maximum number of iterations permitted at each sampling density. If this number is made too low, it will lead to inaccurate results and/or slow down the overall performance of the algorithm by preventing you from making use of information that could have been derived more quickly at the prematurely aborted, more superficial sampling.

input.name: Initial-sampling Final-sampling Sampling-decrement-ratio
input.description: Controls how densely data is sampled during the first iterative cycle of the algorithm for each order of polynomial. Large values generally speed up the registration process because gross misregistration can be detected with fairly superficial sampling of the data. However, choosing an excessively large value can be counterproductive if the algorithm falls into an infinite loop or is led far from the true value by nonrepresentative sampling.

input.name: Threshold Standard
input.description: Defines a minimum voxel value for the standard file. Voxels in the corresponding file with intensities below this value are excluded from analysis when computing the cost function and its derivatives. The value should always be an integer less than the maximum voxel value in the corresponding file.

input.name: Threshold Reslice
input.description: Defines a minimum voxel value for the reslice file. Voxels in the corresponding file with intensities below this value are excluded from analysis when computing the cost function and its derivatives. The value should always be an integer less than the maximum voxel value in the corresponding file.

input.name: Verbose
input.description: Enables verbose reporting of interim results to log file

module.name: Combine Warp
module.description: Mathematically combines a .warp file with any number of compatible .air files to create a single .warp file that directly achieves the spatial transformation described by sequential application of the .air and .warp files.

citations.citation: Woods, R.P., Grafton, S.T., Holmes, C.J., Cherry, S.R., and Mazziotta, J.C. (1998a). Automated image registration: I. General methods and intrasubject, intramodality validation. J Comput Assist Tomogr V22, 139-152. PMID: 9448779

Woods, R.P., Grafton, S.T., Watson, J.D., Sicotte, N.L., and Mazziotta, J.C. (1998b). Automated image registration: II. Intersubject validation of linear and nonlinear models. J Comput Assist Tomogr 22, 153-165. PMID: 9448780

output.name: Output WARP file
output.description: The name of the .warp file to be created.

input.name: Overwrite
input.description: 'y' grants permission to overwrite output

input.name: AIR file (prior)
input.description: An optional sequence of .air files with the standard file of each being spatially equivalent to the reslice file of the one before it.

input.name: WARP file
input.description: The input .warp file, which, if preceded by a .air file, must have a standard file that is spatially equivalent to that .air file's reslice file.

input.name: AIR file (subsequent)
input.description: An optional sequence of .air files, the first of which must have a standard file that is spatially equivalent to the .warp file's reslice file; similarly each subsequent .air file must have a standard file that is spatially equivalent to the preceding .air file's reslice file.

module.license:

module.name: Reslice Warp
module.description: This program takes a .warp file and uses the information that it contains to load the corresponding image file and generate a new, realigned file.

citations.citation: Woods, R.P., Grafton, S.T., Holmes, C.J., Cherry, S.R., and Mazziotta, J.C. (1998a). Automated image registration: I. General methods and intrasubject, intramodality validation. J Comput Assist Tomogr V22, 139-152. PMID: 9448779

Woods, R.P., Grafton, S.T., Watson, J.D., Sicotte, N.L., and Mazziotta, J.C. (1998b). Automated image registration: II. Intersubject validation of linear and nonlinear models. J Comput Assist Tomogr 22, 153-165. PMID: 9448780

input.name: .warp File (Non-linear Transformation)
input.description: name of the warp file containing the nonlinear transformation parameters

output.name: Output Image
output.description: name of the output image file

input.name: Alternate Reslice File
input.description: changes the file to be resliced

input.name: Divide By Intensity Scale Factor
input.description: Scales output by dividing by specified factor

input.name: Divide By Intensity Scale Factor File
input.description: scales output by dividing by factor specified in file

input.name: Interpolation Model Number 0
input.description:
the interpolation model number:
* 0. nearest neighbor * 1. trilinear * 2. windowed sinc in original xy plane, linear along z o requires x- and y- half-window-width arguments * 3. windowed sinc in original xz plane. linear along y o requires x- and z- half-window-width arguments * 4. windowed sinc in original yz plane, linear along x o requires y- and z- half-window-width arguments * 5. 3D windowed sinc o requires x-, y- and z- half-window-width arguments

input.name: Overwrite?
input.description: grants overwrite permission

input.name: Multiplicative Intensity Scale Factor
input.description: scales output using specified multiplicative factor

input.name: Multiplicative Intensity Scale Factor File
input.description: scales output using multiplicative factor specified in file

input.name: Interpolation Model Number 1
input.description:
the interpolation model number:
* 0. nearest neighbor * 1. trilinear * 2. windowed sinc in original xy plane, linear along z o requires x- and y- half-window-width arguments * 3. windowed sinc in original xz plane. linear along y o requires x- and z- half-window-width arguments * 4. windowed sinc in original yz plane, linear along x o requires y- and z- half-window-width arguments * 5. 3D windowed sinc o requires x-, y- and z- half-window-width arguments

input.name: Interpolation Model Number 2
input.description:
the interpolation model number:
* 0. nearest neighbor * 1. trilinear * 2. windowed sinc in original xy plane, linear along z o requires x- and y- half-window-width arguments * 3. windowed sinc in original xz plane. linear along y o requires x- and z- half-window-width arguments * 4. windowed sinc in original yz plane, linear along x o requires y- and z- half-window-width arguments * 5. 3D windowed sinc o requires x-, y- and z- half-window-width arguments

input.name: Interpolation Model Number 3
input.description:
the interpolation model number:
* 0. nearest neighbor * 1. trilinear * 2. windowed sinc in original xy plane, linear along z o requires x- and y- half-window-width arguments * 3. windowed sinc in original xz plane. linear along y o requires x- and z- half-window-width arguments * 4. windowed sinc in original yz plane, linear along x o requires y- and z- half-window-width arguments * 5. 3D windowed sinc o requires x-, y- and z- half-window-width arguments

input.name: Interpolation Model Number 4
input.description:
the interpolation model number:
* 0. nearest neighbor * 1. trilinear * 2. windowed sinc in original xy plane, linear along z o requires x- and y- half-window-width arguments * 3. windowed sinc in original xz plane. linear along y o requires x- and z- half-window-width arguments * 4. windowed sinc in original yz plane, linear along x o requires y- and z- half-window-width arguments * 5. 3D windowed sinc o requires x-, y- and z- half-window-width arguments

input.name: Interpolation Model Number 5
input.description:
the interpolation model number:
* 0. nearest neighbor * 1. trilinear * 2. windowed sinc in original xy plane, linear along z o requires x- and y- half-window-width arguments * 3. windowed sinc in original xz plane. linear along y o requires x- and z- half-window-width arguments * 4. windowed sinc in original yz plane, linear along x o requires y- and z- half-window-width arguments * 5. 3D windowed sinc o requires x-, y- and z- half-window-width arguments

module.name: Reslice Warp
module.description: This program takes a .warp file and uses the information that it contains to load the corresponding image file and generate a new, realigned file.

citations.citation: Woods, R.P., Grafton, S.T., Holmes, C.J., Cherry, S.R., and Mazziotta, J.C. (1998a). Automated image registration: I. General methods and intrasubject, intramodality validation. J Comput Assist Tomogr V22, 139-152. PMID: 9448779

Woods, R.P., Grafton, S.T., Watson, J.D., Sicotte, N.L., and Mazziotta, J.C. (1998b). Automated image registration: II. Intersubject validation of linear and nonlinear models. J Comput Assist Tomogr 22, 153-165. PMID: 9448780

input.name: .warp File (Non-linear Transformation)
input.description: name of the warp file containing the nonlinear transformation parameters

output.name: Output Image
output.description: name of the output image file

input.name: Alternate Reslice File
input.description: changes the file to be resliced

input.name: Divide By Intensity Scale Factor
input.description: Scales output by dividing by specified factor

input.name: Divide By Intensity Scale Factor File
input.description: scales output by dividing by factor specified in file

input.name: Interpolation Model Number 0
input.description:
the interpolation model number:
* 0. nearest neighbor * 1. trilinear * 2. windowed sinc in original xy plane, linear along z o requires x- and y- half-window-width arguments * 3. windowed sinc in original xz plane. linear along y o requires x- and z- half-window-width arguments * 4. windowed sinc in original yz plane, linear along x o requires y- and z- half-window-width arguments * 5. 3D windowed sinc o requires x-, y- and z- half-window-width arguments

input.name: Overwrite?
input.description: grants overwrite permission

input.name: Multiplicative Intensity Scale Factor
input.description: scales output using specified multiplicative factor

input.name: Multiplicative Intensity Scale Factor File
input.description: scales output using multiplicative factor specified in file

the interpolation model number:
* 0. nearest neighbor * 1. trilinear * 2. windowed sinc in original xy plane, linear along z o requires x- and y- half-window-width arguments * 3. windowed sinc in original xz plane. linear along y o requires x- and z- half-window-width arguments * 4. windowed sinc in original yz plane, linear along x o requires y- and z- half-window-width arguments * 5. 3D windowed sinc o requires x-, y- and z- half-window-width arguments

module.name: Combine Diffs
module.description: Combine two .diff files into a single output .diff

input.name: Input1.diff
input.description: First input .diff

input.name: Input2.diff
input.description: Second input .diff

input.name: Swap bytes
input.description: Swap bytes

module.name: reslicediff_dir
module.description: Apply a filelist of .air files to a .diff file. Primary use is to adjust the diffusion gradient table after data has been corrected for motion and/or spatially aligned to a reference space (e.g. MNI brain).

input.name: Input .diff file
input.description: Input .diff file (required).

output.name: Output .diff file
output.description: Output .diff file (even though this is an output, for the pipeline it is treated as an input)

input.name: Input filelist of .airfiles
input.description: List of airfiles. The number of files must equal the number of gradients specified in the input .diff.

input.name: Swap bytes
input.description: Swap bytes of the input .diff. If the bytes need to be swapped for the .air files, the program should figure it out on its own. 0: Do not swap bytes (default) 1: Swap bytes

module.name: FSLMerge (nii.gz)
module.description: Concatenate image files into a single output. This concatenation can be in time, or in X, Y or Z. All image dimensions (except for the one being concatenated over) must be the same in all input images. For example, this can be used to take multiple 3D files (eg as output by SPM) and create a single 4D image file.

citations.citation:
S.M. Smith, M. Jenkinson, M.W. Woolrich, C.F. Beckmann, T.E.J. Behrens, H. Johansen-Berg, P.R. Bannister, M. De Luca, I. Drobnjak, D.E. Flitney, R. Niazy, J. Saunders, J. Vickers, Y. Zhang, N. De Stefano, J.M. Brady, and P.M. Matthews. Advances in functional and structural MR image analysis and implementation as FSL. NeuroImage, 23(S1):208-219, 2004
PMID: 15501092

input.name: Concatenation Type
input.description: Specify the type of concatenation to be applied. The following can be chosen: -x: concatenate images in the x direction. -y: concatenate images in the y direction. -z: concatenate images in the z direction. -t : concatenate images in time. -a: auto-choose: single slices -> volume, volumes -> 4D (time series)

input.name: Input File(s)
input.description: Specifies the input file path. An infinite number of inputs may be specified.

annotation.name: This step corrects the 2D eddy current induced distortions. It should align each image to the first b=0.

style.name: This step corrects the 2D eddy current induced distortions. It should align each image to the first b=0.$0

annotation.name:
This step does the 3D linear motion correction. It should align every image (including the first b=0) to the first b=0. The segment option of 256 is necessary to do multimodal registration. As the b=0 has a different image contrast from the diffusion-weighted images, this is very important.
Alternatively, this step can be used to put the DTI data into a common space, by specifying a different reference image. Note: only rigid body registrations (6 parameters) should be used here in order to correct the gradient table properly.

style.name:
This step does the 3D linear motion correction. It should align every image (including the first b=0) to the first b=0. The segment option of 256 is necessary to do multimodal registration. As the b=0 has a different image contrast from the diffusion-weighted images, this is very important.
Alternatively, this step can be used to put the DTI data into a common space, by specifying a different reference image. Note: only rigid body registrations (6 parameters) should be used here in order to correct the gradient table properly.$0

annotation.name: The combine_warp step allows for only a single orientation per image, reducing the amount of interpolation.

style.name: The combine_warp step allows for only a single orientation per image, reducing the amount of interpolation.$0

annotation.name: Add a data sink here if you want to continue on with the 4D analyze images.

style.name: Add a data sink here if you want to continue on with the 4D analyze images.$0

annotation.name: Combine the two .diff files (1 from each repeated acquisition). Can be called multiple times if there are multiple repeats.

style.name: Combine the two .diff files (1 from each repeated acquisition). Can be called multiple times if there are multiple repeats.$0

annotation.name: Correct the gradient table for the spatial rotations introduced by the motion correction (from previous step). This step is necessary because any time the images are rotated spatially, these rotations must also be applied to the gradient vectors so that the gradient vectors and images correspond for later computations.

style.name: Correct the gradient table for the spatial rotations introduced by the motion correction (from previous step). This step is necessary because any time the images are rotated spatially, these rotations must also be applied to the gradient vectors so that the gradient vectors and images correspond for later computations.$0

annotation.name: Add a data sink here if you want to use the .diff file in later calculations. Add a scandiff module if you are going to continue on with FSL. With scandiff, you can see the corrected gradient vectors in the execution log, or you can specify outputs to "bvecs" and "bvals", which are used in FSL.

style.name: Add a data sink here if you want to use the .diff file in later calculations. Add a scandiff module if you are going to continue on with FSL. With scandiff, you can see the corrected gradient vectors in the execution log, or you can specify outputs to "bvecs" and "bvals", which are used in FSL.$0

annotation.name: Add a data sink here if you want to continue on with the 3D analyze images.

style.name: Add a data sink here if you want to continue on with the 3D analyze images.$0
